relation: Participate in educational events to learn more about pest management
Learn more about the life cycle of the most important insects, weeds and diseases in your plantings
Learn to recognize beneficial insects and/or predators/parasitoids that naturally control pests
Have a current year's copy of Cornell's Pest Management Guide for Commercial Production and Maintenance of Trees and Shrubs
pageTitle: Elements of IPM for Christmas Trees in NY State
TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {16197=These pages are maintained by the New York State IPM Program, part of Cornell Cooperative Extension. All material is protected by Section 107 of the 1976 copyright law. Copyright is held by Cornell University and the New York State IPM Program.}
textBeforeTable: Pre-Plant (Re-Plant) IPM Considerations   Major Pests of Christmas Tree Species: Insects, Diseases, and Weeds Grower IPM Education Nuisance Wildlife Management In-Season Weed Management In-Season Disease Management In-Season Insect Management General Pest Management Crop Management Pre-Growing Season IPM Considerations Pre-Plant (Re-Plant) IPM Considerations CONTENTS: The Elements for Christmas Tree IPM in New York State are designed as a self-evaluation tool for growers already implementing IPM or as an educational tool for growers new to the concepts of IPM.  If you have comments, questions or suggestions please contact Brian Eshenaur bce1@cornell.edu or Elizabeth Lamb eml38@cornell.edu This set of basic elements, of Integrated Pest Management (IPM) may assist growers and in implementing an IPM approach for Christmas trees grown in New York. Not all growers will use all elements as managing pests is an individual and dynamic process influenced by field size, trees grown, weather and new knowledge. download pdf document, 116k Elements for Christmas Tree Production Integrated Pest Management in New York State IPM Events Calendar > elements > nysipm Home ->
textAfterTable: return to top   Pre-Growing Season IPM Considerations Activity Check if done Maintain an inventory of pesticides   If the plans for the year include restricted use pesticides, make sure pesticide use license is current and seek re-certification training as needed   Ensure all personal protective equipment is clean and stored properly   Inspect and clean pesticide storage and mixing areas   Calibrate pesticide application equipment annually   return to top   Crop Management Activity Check if done Use soil analysis, to determine appropriate fertilizer pro­grams   Keep complete records of soil test results and fertilizer applications (rate and timing)   Record dates of budding, and significant weather events   Use growing degree days to schedule your pest management   Test water source(s) used for pesticide mixing for pH and alkalinity   Adjust tree species grown as pest pressures dictate   return to top   General Pest Management Activity Check if done Have a plan for pest management based on time of season, pest biology, pest thresholds, and available management options
